title: Jurgen Klopp: Liverpool boss must play with two defensive midfielders if he wants to beat Chelsea to the title
text:
EFL DANNY HIGGINBOTHAM Jurgen Klopp: Liverpool boss must play with two defensive midfielders if he wants to beat Chelsea to the title 
Reds leaking goals in defence as marauding full-backs leave space and would benefit from an extra man holding the fort Exclusive Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments IT’S more important for clubs at the top end of the table to play two holding midfielders than it is for those at the bottom. 
That may sound counter-intuitive — that the big boys don’t need two defensive bodies camped in the middle against Sunderland or Hull (no disrespect) — but it is not so. PA:Press Association 
And Chelsea and Liverpool offer proof. Keep up to date with ALL the Liverpool news, gossip, transfers and goals on our club page plus fixtures, results and live match commentary 
Chelsea go into today’s clash with Arsenal ten points ahead of Jurgen Klopp’s Reds — but look at their records against so-called smaller teams. Both have lost just three games this season — Liverpool to Bournemouth , Burnley and Swansea , while Chelsea lost to Arsenal, Spurs and Liverpool. 
The reason Klopp’s side have been picked off and Chelsea have ridden roughshod over the lesser lights is down, in part, to having double protection in the middle. They won’t leave themselves vulnerable when they lose the ball. 
Jordan Henderson is good — but he’s not that good. He can’t do what Nemanja Matic and N’Golo Kante do together. 
And with your Sunderlands and Hulls, their midfields will sit deep because they see less of the ball — so they won’t be caught out of shape. Klopp speaks his passion to official in Liverpool v Chelsea game Sun 6 These graphics show Liverpool's average positions against Burnley and Man City 
For Liverpool, only having Henderson doing that role leaves them horribly exposed down the flanks when the rest of the team bomb on. 
Look at our average position maps for Liverpool at Burnley, when they lost 2-0, and the huge areas of space behind the full-backs. 
This is a freebie for teams to counter-attack. Henderson cannot get out and cover. 
It’s a two-man job if the full-backs bomb on. 
Now look at the average position maps for their 1-0 win over Manchester City . They’re much deeper. Related Stories ENEMY WITHIN Gary Neville scores a huge own goal by employing a LIVERPOOL fan to host hospitality at his Old Trafford hotel CLEAR OUT Ian Ayre to leave Liverpool at the end of the month as Reds continue major restructure of hierarchy Mama-doh! Rio Ferdinand says Liverpool have lost their 'best defender' after letting Mamadou Sakho join Palace I'll keep blowing my Klopp Jurgen Klopp tells Jose Mourinho: 'I can't guarantee I won't scream at officials again' after raging at fourth official Getty Images 6 Jordan Henderson has to do all of the defensive donkey work by himself 
The funny thing about these two games is that against Burnley Klopp’s lot had 80 per cent possession. Against City, they had 43 per cent. 
In fact, in Liverpool’s four highest possessions of the season they lost twice (Burnley 80% and Swansea 74%), drew one (Sunderland 71%) and beat (Hull 74%). They also let in eight goals. 
By contrast, in their four lowest possessions of the season, they won three (City 43%, Chelsea 47% and Arsenal 49%) and drew with ( Manchester United 44%), conceding just five goals. 
The point is that Liverpool are better when they’re playing on the counter against big teams. Reuters 6 Liverpool's current formation allows the likes of Adam Lallana to roam further forward 
They know big clubs are going to come at them, so they end up playing as if they have two holding midfielders anyway. This provides balance. 
The same applies in the cups. 
Against Southampton in the EFL Cup semi-finals, they had 68 and 72 per cent possession and lost both legs. And it was 79 per cent when losing to Wolves in the FA Cup. 
You might ask why has this trend just started? Why were they flying early in the season? 
The answer is timing. If they score early, the opposition tend to come out and Liverpool can sit in and be more secure — and strike on the break. Getty Images Someone like Emre Can would bring more balance to midfield and provide cover for the full-backs 
Against Leicester , they won 4-1, but scored on 13 minutes. 
They beat Hull 5-1 but netted the opener in the 17th minute. 
In the 2-1 win over West Brom , they scored on 20, at Crystal Palace when they won 4-2 it was 16, and Watford it was 6-1 after a 27th-minute goal. 
So the majority of early-season wins when Liverpool looked like Premier League contenders were courtesy of early goals. Reuters 6 Lucas Leiva could also be the right man to make Liverpool more stable at the back 
And when they score early they have been happy to cough up the ball. Against West Brom, they had just 61 per cent possession. Against Palace, it was 50 and Watford 60. 
Liverpool are the league’s highest scorers but, at the back, they have conceded the joint-most in the top seven. 
They have shipped 12 more than Chelsea and Spurs — a goal extra every two games. That makes winning the title tough. 
Refs were eager to clamp down on players holding this season. Liverpool seem to be clamping down on holding players — and it’s costing them.
